description.text: A quick test of modeling to 3d print workflow, using iPad app called iDough. This print was run on my MB Replicator at 0.2 mm slicing, cleaned up in Netfab to flatten the base. Used iDough as the mesh creation source.

25 years after art school, 22 years after learning CAD, and 10 years after learning gcode, I would have never conceived that it would be possible to model complex organic geometry on a handheld device and hold a physical output in my hand 90 minutes later at such a low cost. Instructions:
  • install iPad app iDough, $6.99. Fiddle with, learn interface tools. (10 min)
  • create model (2 mins- to hours...how much work depends on you)
  • export .obj file via email from iPad to PC.
  • convert obj to stl in Netfab, make any edits. I trimmed the bottom flat. (3- 5 mins)
  • open stl in ReplicatorG, slice with Skeinforge. (15 min?- didn't watch clock)
  • print on MB Replicator (1 hour, 39 minutes)

comments.text: Just thought I would let people know if you want to try out a free/similar type of sculpting app give 123d sculpt a look. It doesn't let you export your creations (why they don't let you do this I cannot understand but I think they will in future updates.) It has a near identical user interface and is a real pleasure to create sculptures with after a bit of practice. Still, not everyone will like the UI and it is worth a practice with before buying the iDough.
comments.author: Mackeyorama

comments.text: More apps and programs are coming i think. I used MeshMixer couple of weeks ago, also a program for 3d sculpting, i had the same amazed experience how it was possible to do such complex things in such a short time...!
comments.author: Mackeyorama

As the original Ciclop scanner isn't adjustable I removed all the M8 bolts and nuts. By adding an extra feet for the (now) standing tower and arms with a flexible end everything is adjustable.
With cyano acrylate glue the arms are connected to the Tower. But with glueing 4x stop in the 8mm holes, you also can use screws

The camera can be alligned to have a view on the whole disc, just by moving the disc.

By adjusting the M4 inbus bolts the lasers can be adjusted to hit te centre of the disc

Instead of all the M8 stuff you only need 2 times M4x25 bolt +nuts

I am submitting this book character on behalf of my 3rd grade Makers Class. After learning just a few basics about 3D printing they were given the task of creating a character and then using the 3D model as part of their book they wrote. We used permeant makers to color our characters and book creator to create our stories. We invite you to print out this character and add to the attached story or make your own story and post it back to us. We would love your constructive feedback! See all our Characters by searching the tag Turner3D for other Character from our class. Happy writing! We are so excited to be a part of the this amazing community.
Fictional writing Students created 3D characters, colored them and then took pictures of them for an original story idea.

The human powered internet cafe looks at the issues of renewable power generation and aims to educate users to the energy requirements of surfing the internet.
Users are asked to peddle the exercise bikes in order to turn a dynamo which would in turn power the computers. If users fail to peddle hard enough the computer monitors will begin to flicker encouraging them to peddle harder.
The thing would ideally be placed in public areas where all forms of society could view it and try it out for them selves, thus educating as many people as possible.
http://mpkappert.weebly.com/pp-internet.html made for the http://makezine.com/go/makerbot comp...

comments.text: Great concept! I've built a stationary recumbent generator bike, you can only get about 80-100 watts out of the average human legs. They would have to be very low power computers and monitors (should be anyway). Also, with the people pumping out all of the power you may have to worry about sweat getting on everything and a cleaning system!

title: Torture Room - The Rack (for 28mm RPG gaming)

description.text:
EDIT: there was a problem with the file. I've replaced it with one that seems to work. 4/7/17

Over at the DMs Craft, Sam the Beachcomber suggested --

Scatter terrain for a torture room:
bench or table with tongs, clamps, knives;
a rack like in Hero Quest;
a iron maiden;
wall section with chains and cuffs;
or pillar with chains and cuffs.

So I created a rack. Here it is. The actual model will be a bit taller than the one in the picture AND the ropes and manacles will be a bit better defined.

comments.text: This will definitely get use in my dungeons, but I received an error loading this into Cura. I received the same error in your other upload "Copy_of_Torture_Room_ScatterTerrain-_The_Chained_Wallflat" but not in "Copy_of_Torture_Room_ScatterTerrain-_The_Chained_Wall". The files in the Chained pillar upload worked fine.

comments.author: miminadeo1980

title: Prop guard for the Hubsan X4 H107L LED Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I didn't receive the prop guard for the X4 and after 5 min of trying to fly or more accurate, 5 min of crashing, I realised I needed it bad. I tried some of the versions found her at thingiverse but non fitted that well. I think they are made for another version of the X4, so I made a new one.   
I haven't tried it extensively but it has survived a few close encounters with about every wall in my room. It might come lose from the motor if crashing hard so keep an eye on it.  
I have added a second version of the guard that should help protect the props when landing(crashing) upside down. Happens surprisingly often.  
Ok, made a new version. Made the guards on top 5 mm higher. Also open up the ring around the motors and made the holes smaller. This should give a tighter grip. If this is not enough it should be possible to heat up the plastic and close the holes even more.

comments.text: Fits perfectly on Hubsan X4 (version without cam). Its a bit heavy but no problem for good flight performane. Because of this the flight is very stable. Very good for beginners. Thanks
comments.author: mr_cg

comments.text: Yes, I never optimized it for weight. I have never taken the time.
comments.author: Gwyrlim

comments.text: I was going t say your guard looked a tiny bit heavy, but I admire the design you made.  What sort of flight times where you getting with your guard?
comments.author: Monkeyking1969

comments.text: I had never seen the original before making this. Now I have received the original and it is quit different. Much leaner and softer. Doubt it is possible to print one like it unless you us some other kind of plastic, nylon perhaps.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Just wondering.. Did you look on the underside of the packing plastic?  They tape the bumpers there away from everything else.  Regardless, your print looks like it may be better than the one provided so I'd say it's a good thing you didn't get one. :)

title: Y and Z cable chain to Extruder for Anet A8 - left side
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While thinking how to make the Z-chain in my old mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2218879) I had the idea to mount everything on top of the acrylic frame.

V1 is very simple and uses the cable chain ends from Modelstation.

With V2 you can use aanother cable chain for the wires down to the Mainboard/CPU.
Both Version are compatible with many cable chains out there and my cable chain with clips:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208675
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2232788

Both versions need the "XY_Chain_top_left_rod_fixation".

Mount for extruder (right side):
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2218895

comments.text: That is one original approach to z axis chain! I'll look back into this design when I move to AM8 frame.
comments.author: kamilblk

comments.text: I cannot believe nobody has tried this, all the others I have looked at would cause me to lose some z height and would cause binding at certain height. I have printed and modified my x axis chain so many times and I just got sick and tired of trying to improve it so my wires would bind.
comments.author: bigmike85

comments.text:

thank you.
The chain links I like the most are design by me :-) based on the links from Modelstation which is like a standard.

I also made some longer links adopted from Starwhoopers design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2232788
This could be helpfull if you have the electronics outside the enclosure.

author: PedroRenaut

description.text:
This mount is designed for the E3D Titan extruder and Wilson TS X-carriage mounting style (similar to the Prusa i3 Rework).

I wasn't happy with the other mount designs requiring me to remove the entire X-carriage, so I designed this one to simply mount with (4) M3 screws similar to how the existing Wilson extruder was designed. I also added a mounting point for my 8mm capacitive sensor, but could change this depending on what people request.

The E3D fan mount is from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1746358 as I couldn't find a way to mount my 5015 fan in a way that made me happy. I also like how this design replicates the Prusa MK2 design as it keeps the entire extruder very small.

Please comment if you have any suggestions or would like to see other mounting styles.

Source: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f45f2f2c8dee46c4959c253d/w/619ca1b93de64bfa9a785358/e/d36a872bbee218f96f564685
OnShape

comments.text: Thanks, not 100% convinced on the fan mounting arrangement but I guess if it works then fine.  I need to modify this to accommodate my Aus3D IR probe.
comments.author: JBFUK

comments.text: It would also be great to get a BLTouch sensor mount option. I wish I was better at using OnShape.
comments.author: Phaedrux

comments.text: Would it be possible to get a version to use with the Titan Aero? I was able to get it to fit by carving out a notch for the heatsink and a small hole for a screw that sticks out. You can see what I mean here: http://imgur.com/a/lMvDZ
comments.author: Phaedrux

comments.text: I can revise the body for the Aero but it would take me longer to adjust for a BL Touch sensor.  Give it a try if you have a chance, Onshape is a bit difficult to learn at first but once you get the key concepts it really opens up.
comments.author: Phaedrux

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. I've managed to get it to fit as it is, though I'm not sure how hot the heat sink will get. Currently printed in pla to test. Final part would be petg.
comments.author: cfunseth

comments.text: Hey, I'm considering printing this and I was wondering if you could make the holder for the sensor a little bit thicker? It seems a little wobbly as it is.
comments.author: Scoof

comments.text: For the 8mm sensor?
comments.author: Scoof

comments.text: No, for the 18mm diameter sensor, I meant higher so it could be less wobbly. I have a similar design on my MK2S extruder and I had to secure it with a ziptie because the cable tension used to make it move slightly on certain part of the bed.
comments.author: cfunseth

comments.text: I could beef up the bottom of the hole, but I don't think that would do much for addressing the flex.  I have my cables arranged so that I don't have any deflection while moving the print head.  Not sure if you have any ideas on changing the design?
comments.author: Scoof

comments.text: It's Ok I printed as is but my stepper motor is too large for this mount anyway, I had to print another one. (used the motor provided by E3D)

title: Solid Endstop Holder for 2020 Kossel Delta Mini

description.text:
Best endstop holder ever? There are many endstops holders out there. With this design, I tried to position the switch at the middle of the 2020 aluminium profile.
Fixing the switch to the holder: I want to provide a solid m3 nut fix and three optional holes to further stabilize it, if necessary.
Fixing the holder to the profile: Since the holder is fixed to the profile by a single m3 screw and T-nut this holder grabs into the 2020 profile, so it should be pretty stable.

This solution should go well with sintron delta kossel mini or He3D DLT-180 standard parts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566093
It is part of my attempt to enhance the carriage part of these delta printers with an adjustable screw that hits the centered endstop perfectly: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2236000

I helped a friend set up his media room with projector and electric screen. The wall where the screen is mounted rises 6' from the floor, but then is slanted at a 45" angle for about 3 feet before meeting the horizontal ceiling. Hanging the screen flat on the wall would put it too close to the floor. Hanging it from the flat ceiling would bring it forward too close to the seating. The projector screen came with standard L brackets for mounting to either the wall or ceiling, so we needed a way to mount the brackets to the angled portion of the ceiling. This is my solution.

I printed the pieces at 100% infill to make sure they are strong and solid. We used screws through the mounting holes into either studs or metal wall anchors. Because I didn't have the L brackets on hand I left the mounting surface solid and then drilled holes on site to make sure the brackets fit perfectly. (bracket pics attached)

title: Guitar Pick Holder with Pen-Spring Mechinism

description.text: I took k1nc41d's pick holder design and removed the rubber band guides, because I don't like rubber bands, and added holders for a spring I sprung from a clicky-pen. The opening the picks come out of is large enough for a thick weight pick, or two mediums, but I haven't had an issue with pulling just one out. As the original was licensed GPL, this is too.

You'll print the three pieces, either together in one go, or seperate and then clean them up so the pick-looking piece slides easily in the box-looking piece and the lid piece sits on the box-looking piece. When you put the pick piece in the box piece, you want the peg on the pick piece to be aimed towards the peg on the lid piece. These pegs will hold a spring in place.  
Take it all apart again, and find a retractable pen with a nice clicky spring. Destroy the pen. Get the spring from wherever it landed under the table.  
Depending on how long it is, you'll have to snip it shorter, so it fits in the box piece between the lid and pick pieces.  You want the spring to be just long enough that it holds the pick piece at the top of the box piece with a little force when you put the lid piece on. You want the spring to hold the pick piece against the top (open end) of the box piece without the spring falling out of place, but not pressing so hard that you can't get picks in.  
You'll need some glue. Did I mention that? Well, you will. Something that will bond well with the plastic you are using. Acetone could work. So could a drop of gorilla superglue, which is what I'm using.   
Use a drop of glue to hold the spring on the peg of the pick piece. Once that's dry, use another drop of glue to hold the other end of the spring to the peg on the lid piece. Let this glue dry too.  
Now that it is all dry, slide the pick piece into the box piece and then use a drop or three of your glue to hold the lid piece in place on the box piece. Hold it until the spring won't push them apart again.   
Now let it dry over night. Tomorrow you can put picks in it. Don't put picks in it tonight, the added pressure from the picks on the spring could push apart glue that hasn't set yet. Now put your picks in! And then take one out and ROCK ON!

description.text: Canton du Valais, Suisse.

Sous linux: Avec Inkskape, effectuer une courbe qui suis les frontières du Valais, avec une image tirée de Google en arrière-plan. Enregistrer en svg. Importer le svg dans blender, le transformer en Mesh et l'extruder verticalement. Importer le stl de la Suisse de gluetolf dans le même document blender. Faire coincider les 2 objets de telle sorte que le contour du Valais traverse vertivalement la Suisse et dépasse bien en haut et en bas. Effectuer une opération booléenne "intersect" sur la Suisse. Si le Valais disparaît et les autres cantons restent, il faut inverser les normales du Valais. Boire l'apéro pendant l'impression de l'objet!
Pour l'effet sommet enneigé, j'ai coupé le filament gris pendand l'impression et j'ai inséré un filament blanc.

This is like my other bolt knob pressed on conversions. It makes a 1/4 inch bolt head into a toolless knob head. I like to keep things that need quick conversion or mounting and un-mounting quickly to not require tools if not necessary. The knob helps a lot. This is an addition to my line of 3/8 inch knobs. It is easily pressed onto the bolt head in a vice or press. I printed mine with PETG filament at 100% infill for strength.

I also included the (.sldprt) SolidWorks 2013 file and a STEP file for you all to create your own sizes and shapes. This is what I made for my own application. I bolt down a Dillon RL 550C bullet press to my work bench when I want to use it. Yet, I can easily and quickly remove it when I need the bench for something else like my vice. The vice I bolt down with my low profile 3/8 inch bolt knobs into a different set of T-Nuts or nut inserts preset in my work bench surface. Enjoy!

title: Nintendo Switch Comfort Grip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: For anyone without access to a 3D printer, you can now buy V3 from Spencer on his Etsy store: http://www.etsy.com/shop/3DPrinterSpencer

Update 5/21/2017: Added a new version (V3). I think it strikes the best balance between size, comfort and easy reach to shoulder buttons. I also updated the screenshots to easily see the differences. I included a split version of V3 for smaller printers.

Here is a great video of V3 being printed by ModBot: https://youtu.be/8MzNG5oqPlI He goes over what print settings were used and what it feels like to use it with the switch. Thanks, ModBot!

Update 5/4/2017: Added two new versions (V2A and V2B whole). Some people mentioned it was difficult to hit the shoulder buttons, so that inspired me to try and fix that in the next version. I ended up making one that was really compact (version V2B) and thought I need to make one that was in the middle ground (V2A). Check out the comparison screenshots.

Original Text:
When you use the switch in portable mode for extended play sessions those hands start to cramp. I aimed for an Xbox style set of grips for the system while in portable mode.

I took a previous model of a controller by ant385645 for the shape of the grips.

I included a split version for smaller print beds but keep in mind you might have to sand the connecting rails a little to make them fit. I would recommend getting the whole version as it will probably be much sturdier.

Make sure you print the whole thing (or all split pieces) standing upright so the support material is only on the bottom faces and it keeps the slot part for the tablet as smooth as possible.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Make sure it is printed standing up right like in the first picture. If it is printed face down, the slot will not be wide enough (because of sagging) and you'll use a lot more support material than needed.

comments.text: I printed one of these on my Anet A8 out of the box and it was great. Gave it to my brother. Then I printed another for myself after getting the printer dialed in. The gap is 1,45mm too wide, the switch won't stay in there, I printed another version to try and same problem. I imported it to fusion 360 and checked the measurements, the design as far as I can see has a gap of 240,45mm while the switch is 239mm wide :( I really like the design work but It would have been nice if it was the right size :( Hope I'm not barking up the wrong tree here.

comments.text: I have just added pics of the printed result. I roughly sanded it to smooth it out so it looks discolored but it feels great! One good tip is that you can chose to add a small layer of foam to the inside of the bottom slots to get the tablet to sit at your preferred height. Adding some foam to move the tablet up on makes it easier to use the right stick for games that use that stick a lot. The width of the foam you add can also let you customize how inset the ZL and ZR shoulder buttons feel. With more foam they stick out more if that feels better on your grip.

title: Z-axis endstop block for Ultimaker Original +

description.text:
This is an improvement for the Ultimaker Original Z-end switch.

If you thighten the screws of the end switch, it turns and your setting is gone. This part has four claws, that grip into the slotted holes and prevents the switch from turning.

The second improvement is that it sets the end switch 4 mm form the wall. Thus the end switch gets reliable contact with the tab on the Z stage.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

• Remove the z-switch
  • put the part into the slotted holes FROM THE INSIDE OF THE PRINTER. The claws gripp into the holes.
  • Reinstall the z-switch. The original screws are long enough.
  • Readjust the z-stage.

Hint: to adjust the z-stage put a cd under the nozzle (silver side up!!!). It ist aproximately 1.1 mm thick. In the moment the nozzle touches the CD you have to hear the click.

description.text:
This is a speaker mount for a Logitech Z-5500 speaker (Not the center speaker). It is designed to mount on a 35mm pole monitor mount. (Something like this https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=9SIA3BG3TE0639)

I have two of these poles so I can mounted it on either side of my desk. Most people probably only have 1 so this wouldn't help much. Unless You mount them right on top of each other.

If was was going to design this again I think I would make the clap a little bit thicker. As this one it looks like it is under a little bit of stress after I installed it. But I am not to concerned about it.

This is a 10 pencil jig for a laser/cnc machine. I use the 3dpburner2 laser.

Steps after printing:
Square the jig to machine.
Edit the SVG (I use inkscape). Make sure to make text to path using Object to Path
Export text layer as DXF
Import into machine settings
Burn/Cut

For my laser I dialed it back to a little less than 50% intensity.
I also spaced the letters apart a little to get them looking crisper.

You know your machine better than I do so it may take some experimenting before you get a good result. Pencils are cheap.

MP3DP

Doesn't Matter

.3

50-60

title: Mendel90 X Carriage for Titan Aero

description.text:
Been playing around with building a Mendel90 when I saw E3D's Titan Aero and thought why not add it to the build. This is my first upload to Thingiverse, hopefully, this helps someone else. I have it printed and installed, tomorrow I will try printing with it.

I have attached the AutoCAD files and also igs files if you want to alter it.

Note on the diffuser: The Titan Aero is compact, that is both good and bad. There isn't much room around the rods. For the Mendel90 it is hard to get it low enough for the nozzle to clear the rods/bearings and not have the motor sit on the rods either. The hardest part was to fit the diffuser into the design in between the rods. I have printed and installed this design and it fits well around the rods. When the blower is on it works great at pushing air out by and not on the nozzle. Never had a printer with a blower/diffuser, hoping when I print something tomorrow I will see a difference.

comments.text:
Keep up the good work!
Have you thought about adding a Z-Probe mount right into the carriage?
